data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An evergreen shrub or small tree (Camellia sinensis) native to Asia, having fragrant, nodding, cup-shaped white flowers and glossy leaves.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The young, dried leaves of this plant, prepared by various processes and used to make a beverage, usually served hot.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An aromatic, slightly bitter beverage made by steeping tea leaves in boiling water.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various plants, such as New Jersey tea, having leaves that are or were formerly used to make a tealike beverage.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various beverages made by steeping the leaves of certain plants, such as peppermint.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various beverages made by extracting an infusion from meat, especially beef.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An afternoon refreshment consisting usually of sandwiches and cakes served with tea.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
